findings: AI enables real-time processing of sensor data (camera, radar, LiDAR) for autonomous driving functions
Edge AI processes data locally in vehicles for real-time decision making, addressing 1+ GB/second data generation
Manufacturers are progressing from Level 0 to Level 4 autonomous driving capabilities
AI optimizes vehicle design through simulation-driven approaches for aerodynamics and crash safety
Multiple ADAS domain controller architectures are competing in the market with different sensor approaches
AI personalizes infotainment systems and monitors driver fatigue for enhanced safety
Manufacturing benefits from AI-powered smart robotics, predictive maintenance, and automated quality inspection
risks: Continued uncertainty around autonomy and safety standards
Risk of blaming human drivers for autonomy failures
Industry fragmentation with multiple competing architectures
Dependence on AI systems introduces new failure points and maintenance requirements
Implementation requires overcoming technical and operational barriers
recommendations: Adopt diverse sensor modalities beyond just vision and radar for robust autonomous systems
Implement effective driver monitoring systems to address responsibility concerns
Balance edge AI processing with cloud capabilities for optimal performance
Standardize ADAS domain controller architectures to reduce industry fragmentation
Address regulatory and safety considerations for autonomous vehicle deployment
